abstract.p: Beatrice Farnsworth letter says Jonathan Kozol's Aug 22 Op-Ed article about his father's Alzheimer's disease may have created erroneous impression that victims of disease tend to be peaceful and comfortable; says people should be aware of disease's awful aspects so that they might support allocation of money to find preventions and cures

block.p: Jonathan Kozol's Aug. 22 Op-Ed article about his father's Alzheimer's disease may create the impression that victims of this dreadful disease tend to be peaceful and comfortable.

Mr. Kozol is blessed because his father appears to have been spared the all-too-common terrors of Alzheimer's that accompany the memory loss: the nightmarish hallucinations; the anxiety, despite medication; and the crying out.

If Alzheimer's disease reaches predicted epidemic proportions as the population lives longer, people should be aware of the disease's awful aspects so that they might support the allocation of money to find preventions and cures.
